div.p: RBG Kew, Kew correspondence, Australia, Mueller, 1858-70, un-numbered folio after f. 44.

Your consignment of dried specimens of dried plants arrived since the despatch of the last mail & I have to tender you my cordial thanks for this valuable contribution to our public collection.
See J. Hooker to M, 26 December 1859. My joy about them would have been greater still, had they arrived in good condition. But who could have anticipated, that so old a bussiness-Gentleman as Mr Pamplin would allow such treasures to proceed on their long seavoyage without being packed in a metal-lined case. Thus many of the specimens, as well as books were greatly damaged by damp.

In better order arrived the valuable 3 fascicle of the Tasmanian Flora
J. Hooker (1860). Fascicle 3 was published on 17 October 1856; M is evidently referring to the third fascicle of part 2, published 15 February 1859 (TL2), for he discusses below a the moss species omitted from it. which you were so generous to send by Dr Seemann.
See notes to M to W. Hooker, 20 April 1860. Accept for them & their friendly manifestations towards me my cordial acknowledgement.

In the bustle of the planting season, I have only been able to cast my eye over the pages & the fascicles being at the binders, I cannot enter much into details about all what you say. I find however that you omitted to enumerate Donatia Novae Zeelandiae from Mount Laperouse, also Panax sambucifolius
P. sambucifolium? from the E. Coast of VDL and Triodontium, unless this moss is reduced to some other genus. I am engaged now on a review of Eucalypti. Thus I find, that E. gigantea is probably the original E. obliqua, as your venerable father already thought in the Bot Magazine when publishing Backhouse's notes.
In W. Hooker (1827-64), vol. 69, tab 4036 (published 1843), W. Hooker suggested that Backhouse’s ‘stringy barks’ — the 'Stringy-bark Gum' described by Joseph Hooker in J. Hooker (1860), part 1, pp. 136-7 as Eucalyptus gigantea — were possibly E. obliqua. Lamark,
Lamarck (1791-1823), vol. 3, t. 422. who I believed copied from L'Heritier
L'Héritier (1788), t. 20. could not have given a more faithful representation. I reduce the 14 Tasm Eucal to 9!

In your list of Indo-Australian plants
J. Hooker had sent proof sheets of his list of Indo-Australian plants, later published as pp. xlii-xlix of the 'Introductory Essay' to his Flora Tasmaniae (J. Hooker (1860)), also published separately as J. Hooker (1859a). (See J. Hooker to M, 26 December 1859.) (i.e. species) you omitted several exempli gratia: Potamogeton tenuicaulis which Tuckermann
Edward Tuckerman. considers quite distinct from P hybridus (conf. Fragm phytogr. Austr. p. 244)
B59.13.04. In an additional note on P. Tenuicaulis, M quotes an opinion from 'E Tuckermann in litteris'.
Sterculia foetida mentioned by R Br; also Sclerachne punctata RBr found by me in Arnhems Land., Capparis incanescens & divaricata — amongst genera Bambusa, Sciadophyllum, Nepenthes, Musa &c. In your remarks on the missing of so many Indian forms, I would say, that we may still expect them to exist on mountains, such as Mt Bellenden Ker in N.E. Australia 5000'. It is to the absence of mountains alone in N. & N.W. Austr that I adscribe the absence of Balsamin[eae], Begoniaceae, Quercus & endless other Indian mountain forms.

The flora of West Austr is richer as you had the means of ascertaining. Mr Oldfield brought from thence Heterodendrum oleifolium, Nitraria Billardierii & other Eastern Australian forms & from E. Mt Barren & the Phillips River I have many identical Murray desert plants!

I have acted on your kind suggestion
See J. Hooker to M, 26 December 1859 & written to Mr Thwaites for Senna seeds.
Letter not found. Our great desiderata are amongst others Quadria heterophylla & Erythroxylum coca,
Two of the plants referred to contain pharmaceutically active ingredients: Senna pods (Cassia fistula) containing a laxative and Erythroxylum coca is the source of cocaine. Quadria heterophylla (= Gevuina avellana) produces an edible fruit, and was of commercial importance in Chile in the mid-nineteenth century, where the fruits were known colloquially as ‘Avellana’ (=hazelnut) (Gay, 1845–[54], vol. 5. pp 311-2). but I do not know where to obtain them. I have a box with seeds, specimens, barks &c packed for Kew. By next mail I shall be able to say, in what vessel this consignment went.
Many thanks for the seeds & plants pr Great Brittain. Many of the latter suffered & the old fatality carried the Nuphar & the Papyrus off.

div.p:
When you drew your comparison between the opportunities the meritorious Cunningham had for botanizing with those, which a series of fortunate circumstances afforded to my self, you could not know, that I travelled now 19, 000 miles by land in various lines, 5000 miles in various lines in South Austr on private expense of mine from 1847-1852. 6000 miles in Vict 1853-1855 & 1857-1859. 6000 miles in N. Austr 1855-1856. I have botanical diaries of all these journies.
M’s botanical diaries have not been found. In the Introductory Essay to his Flora Tasmaniae (J. Hooker (1860)), Hooker wrote: 'Dr. Mueller has also distinguished himself in several scientific capacities, and, for extent and range of his journeys, ranks second to Allan Cunningham alone of all Australian botanical explorers' (p. cxiii). M was praised in a number of places in the introductory essay, and in the specific account of M's efforts, Hooker wrote 'Dr. Ferdinand Mueller's extensive journeys and important labours ... extend already over a period of ten years of uninterrupted exertion in travelling, or collecting and describing, often under circumstances of great hardship and difficulty, and are of very great merit and importance' (p. cxxii).

When I furnished my notes on Austr Botany in Kew Miscell 185[2] I had examined carefully & analyzed
1500
spec of South Austr phanerogamous plants collected without any aid of the state.
Presumably B53.03.01 and B53.04.02. The papers were read before the Linnean Society on 7 and 21 December 1852. Not enjoying then the friendship of British Botanists few of these ever reached your islands, but they are mostly in Continal
Continental? Museums deposited, an entire set being only in Melbourne.
